name: Forest of Bowland - Short
description: The Altura Forest of Bowland Sportive is a tough early-season test for the legs but you will be given just reward with superb sights and scenery as the Cumbria sportive rolls through two Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty. At the start, the sportive leads out towards Milnthorpe Sands as the route enters its first Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty of the day, Arnside and Silverdale. After a stint on the River Kent, the route dives south to Carnforth and on to the first course split. Short riders peel off west. Winding its way through the surrounding fells and rivers, the course gives some of the best views the area has to offer. Reaching the edge of Clitheroe, the sportive heads north, climbing up to the top of the Newton Fells before descending to continue onto Slaidburn. The return leg across the Forest of Bowland climbs higher than before, granting you glorious views of the Tatham Fells until you reach High Bentham, at which point the route heads east through the village of Hornby. Leaving the National Park at Gressingham, the route continues to wind its way north for the final miles until reaching the finish line

name: Forest of Bowland - Standard
description: The Altura Forest of Bowland Sportive is a tough early-season test for the legs with over 1900m of climbing to tackle but you will be given just reward with superb sights and scenery as the Cumbria sportive rolls through two Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty. At the start, the sportive leads out towards Milnthorpe Sands as the route enters its first Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty of the day, Arnside and Silverdale. After a stint on the River Kent, the route dives south to Carnforth and on to the first course split. Standard participants bear south to our second AONB of the day, the Forest of Bowland, where the course centres its loop for much of the rest of the ride, while also bringing about one of the toughest challenges in the Trough of Bowland.Winding its way through the surrounding fells and rivers, the course gives some of the best views the area has to offer. Reaching Dunsop Bridge the course splits for the last time as Standard riders head west. Reaching the edge of Clitheroe, the sportive heads north, climbing up to the top of the Newton Fells before descending to continue onto Slaidburn. The return leg across the Forest of Bowland climbs higher than before, granting you glorious views of the Tatham Fells until you reach High Bentham, at which point the route heads east through the village of Hornby. Leaving the National Park at Gressingham, the route continues to wind its way north for the final miles until reaching the finish line

name: Forest of Bowland - Epic
description: The Altura Forest of Bowland Sportive is a tough early-season test for the legs with over 2400m of climbing to tackle but you will be given just reward with superb sights and scenery as the Cumbria sportive rolls through two Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty. At the start, the sportive leads out towards Milnthorpe Sands as the route enters its first Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty of the day, Arnside and Silverdale. After a stint on the River Kent, the route dives south to Carnforth and on to the first course split. Epic participants bear south to our second AONB of the day, the Forest of Bowland, where the course centres its loop for much of the rest of the ride, while also bringing about one of the toughest challenges in the Trough of Bowland. Winding its way through the surrounding fells and rivers, the course gives some of the best views the area has to offer. Reaching Dunsop Bridge the course splits for the last time as Epic entrants continue south for an additional 460m of climbing. Reaching the edge of Clitheroe, the sportive heads north, climbing up to the top of the Newton Fells before descending to continue onto Slaidburn. The return leg across the Forest of Bowland climbs higher than before, granting you glorious views of the Tatham Fells until you reach High Bentham, at which point the route heads east through the village of Hornby. Leaving the National Park at Gressingham, the route continues to wind its way north for the final miles until reaching the finish line

name: London Revolution 2018 Day 1
description: The South London Leg - Cycle 160 kilometres through the iconic London sights, over the North Downs to Windsor Racecourse. Stage 1 - Cycle past the Shard and over Tower Bridge before witnessing the historic HMS Belfast. You’ll then venture South into Dulwich past Crystal Palace. Stage 2 - Follow the wheels of many Olympians who tackled these roads in the 2012 Games. Stage 3 - Your final leg into basecamp takes you through the idyllic Ewhurst, you’ll conquer Pitcher Hill one of the many beast’s along the North Downs

name: London Revolution 2018 Day 2
description: The North London Leg Buster - Cycle 140 kilometres from Windsor Racecourse, over the Chilterns and through Epping Forest, before finishing in Enfield. Stage 4 - Ride through beautiful Marlow, along the Thames Valley. Enjoy the scenic Buckinghamshire countryside before you hit the highs of the Chilterns. Stage 5 - Historic villages, buoyant market towns and traditional English pubs are all home to the idyllic countryside that you pedal on through, before hitting the lumpy Chilterns. Stage 6 - You’ll finish the ride in style, through the historic Epping Forest and back to Enfield to complete your full ‘revolution’ of our iconic capital city.

name: Surrey Hills Training
description: Good way to train for hills

name: Winter Training Route To Staplehurst & Back
description: Hayes-Shoreham-Plaxtol-Staplehurst This is the route used by the racing squad for winter training because it includes around 30 miles of flat terrain just 871m of climbing

name: South Downs Spring - Standard
description: If you haven’t blown the winter cobwebs off your bike with a fast and free-flowing ride this far into the year, this April sportive set amongst the stunning South Downs of Sussex is likely just the event to ease you back into the saddle. Not forgetting this ride’s challenging hills, the Cycling Weekly Spring Sportive matches great climbs with the best descents that sprawl through stunning open country lanes. Kicking off in pretty Plumpton, the route heads east on unassuming back roads that can be taken at speed if so desired. As much as the hills on this route are a welcome challenge, you’ll be out of your saddle and counting on every last bit of winter training you have for the toughest ascents. Flirting with the most infamous hills in the area, riders are taken around the base of some fearsome climbs but the route tends to stick to luxurious rolling roads tucked away from traffic. Exploring East Sussex, sleepy villages are taken in one by one before reaching the outskirts of Heathfield – but this ride stays true to its countryside routes as it soon reaches back into the wilderness. Taking in a loop out past Five Ashes and back past High Hurstwood, you’ll be taken past Buxted and towards Uckfield on roads that remain mostly flat, quiet and long ranging. The route then leads north before crossing back into Mid-Sussex and turning south just before it crosses the River Ouse. A shining sun and helpful tailwind are enough to push you along for one last boost towards the finish line – which finishes on a mostly downward slope. You’ll cross the finish line feeling enthralled

name: Emitremmus Desrever - 2017
description: Emitremmus Desrever is our celebration of the end of summertime and the route is essentially the reverse of the middle-distance Start of summertime route. In addition to this, from 2011 we also offered a shorter Lite version of the Emitremmus. This event has grown to a point where we now have well over 400 entrants each year to this event and because of this, we encourage everyone to enter as early as possible to guarantee a place. Event Information We offer two different distances for this event. Both routes start and finish on the same roads but the middle follows different routes.

name: Emitremmus Desrever Lite - 2017
description: Emitremmus Desrever is our celebration of the end of summertime and the route is essentially the reverse of the middle-distance Start of summertime route. In addition to this, from 2011 we also offered a shorter Lite version of the Emitremmus. This event has grown to a point where we now have well over 400 entrants each year to this event and because of this, we encourage everyone to enter as early as possible to guarantee a place. Event Information We offer two different distances for this event. Both routes start and finish on the same roads but the middle follows different routes.

name: Weald of Kent
description: Level 3 Route. 1000m of climbing concentrated at the beginning and end of the route, with approx 25 miles of flat section in the middle. Shoreham, Otford, Kemsing, Ightham, Ivy Hatch, Shipbourne, Underriver, Chiddingstone, Hever, Edenbridge, Tandridge, Oxted, Titsey Hill, Clarks Lane, Berrys Green and Downe.

name: Woldingham, Sundridge Hill Loop
description: Difficulty: 3/4 Route overview: Hayes – Woldingham – Knockholt – Cudham – Downe – Hayes This is one of our Saturday morning routes. It takes in some climbs as well as a fast section of Pilgrims Way. This is not for beginners. You should allow 3 hours but fitter riders will get round in 2hrs – 2hrs 30mins

name: Shop front to sea front
description: Difficulty: 3/4 Route overview: Hayes – Botley Hill – Godstone – Crawley – Waringlid – Brighton. A superb rural route all the way down to Brighton, taking in Devils Dyke instead of Ditchling Beacon

name: Cowden Loop
description: Difficulty: 3/4 Route overview: Hayes – Limpsfield – Lingfield – Cowden – Bough Beech – Ide Hill – Knockholt – Downe – Hayes. Lovely ride on quiet roads, some with surpringly good surfaces. Be prepared for some climbing near the end up Ide Hill and Star Hill

name: Winter Training Route To Staplehurst & Back
description: Difficulty: 4/5 Route overview: Hayes-Shoreham-Plaxtol-Staplehurst This is the route used by the racing squad for winter training because it includes around 30 miles of flat terrain just 871m of climbing

name: Turners Hill Loop
description: Difficulty: 3/4 Route overview: Hayes – Godstone – Smallfield – Copthorne – Turners Hill – East Grinstead – Lingfield – Tatsfield – Biggin Hill – Hayes. A fairly straight route out and back with steady climbing on the way and over Turners Hill before a quick return route
